title: 107_s2592
content: The Act may be cited as the "Living Equitably: Grandparents Aiding Children and Youth Act of 2002" or the "LEGACY Act of 2002". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Living Equitably: Grandparents Aiding Children and Youth Act of 2002" or the "LEGACY Act of 2002," defines terms such as "child," "covered family," "elderly person," and "grandparent." The term "grandparent" is defined as an individual who is a grandparent or stepgrandparent of a child by blood or marriage, regardless of age. It also includes individuals related to an adopted child. An "intergenerational dwelling unit" is a qualified dwelling reserved for intergenerational families with an elderly head of household. A "private nonprofit organization" is defined as per the Housing Act of 1959. A "qualified dwelling unit" must have at least 2 bedrooms and design features for elderly and young children. "Raising a child" means residing with and being the primary caregiver for the child. The term "relative" refers to an individual who is not a parent of the child by blood or marriage. The primary caregiver for a child is someone who takes care of the child when the biological or adoptive parents are not available, regardless of any legal relationship with the child. The term "relative" refers to an individual who is not a parent of the child by blood or marriage, regardless of the age of the individual. In the case of adoption, it includes a relative of the family who adopted the child. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM FOR ELDERLY HOUSING FOR INTERGENERATIONAL FAMILIES. The Secretary will implement a demonstration program to assist intergenerational families with housing under the supportive housing program. Assistance will be provided to nonprofit organizations to expand intergenerational dwelling units by retrofitting existing units or developing new buildings solely for this purpose. The demonstration program aims to assist intergenerational families with housing by developing new buildings solely for this purpose, including elder cottage housing opportunity units. Assistance provided will be subject to the provisions of the Housing Act of 1959. The demonstration program for intergenerational families under the Housing Act of 1959 allows for tailored services, coordination with other agencies, and waivers of certain provisions to provide assistance. The Secretary will establish application procedures for private nonprofit organizations to apply for assistance under the demonstration program. Not less than 2 and not more than 4 projects assisted under section 202 of the Housing Act of 1959 will be selected based on the ability to develop intergenerational dwelling units and national geographical diversity. A report analyzing the effectiveness of the program must be submitted to Congress within 36 months of enactment. The demonstration program under section 202 of the Housing Act of 1959 will receive funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006, with reserved sums for assistance. The program will terminate 5 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM FOR RENTAL ASSISTANCE FOR GRANDPARENT-HEADED OR RELATIVE-HEADED FAMILIES. The Secretary will implement a demonstration program to provide rental assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 for covered families. Public housing agencies selected for the program will offer rental assistance for qualified dwelling units, along with tailored supportive services for children and covered families. The Secretary will establish application procedures for public housing agencies to participate in a demonstration program providing rental assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937. Not less than 2 and not more than 4 agencies will be selected based on their ability to offer assistance and services, with a report due to Congress within 36 months of enactment. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program for rental assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937. A report analyzing the program's effectiveness will be submitted to Congress. Funding will be reserved for rental assistance from amounts available under section 8(o) for fiscal years starting in 2003. The program will terminate 5 years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY OF GRANDPARENT-HEADED AND RELATIVE-HEADED FAMILIES FOR FAMILY UNIFICATION ASSISTANCE. Section 8(x) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include provisions for family assistance under certain conditions, as defined in the LEGACY Act of 2002. The LEGACY Act of 2002 provides assistance for rental of qualified dwelling units under specific conditions outlined in Section 8(x) of the United States Housing Act of 1937. The LEGACY Act of 2002 provides assistance for rental of qualified dwelling units under specific conditions outlined in Section 8(x) of the United States Housing Act of 1937, including assistance for covered families. SEC. 6 of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include cottage housing opportunity units for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families. These units must be installed adjacent to existing 1- to 4-family dwellings, occupied by children who are members of covered families, and facilitate the habitation of covered families as a single family unit. SEC. 7. Assistance under Fair Housing Initiatives Program for education and outreach regarding housing opportunities for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families. Section 561 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to include education, outreach, counseling, and assistance programs for informing families about affordable housing opportunities and services. This amendment also covers housing programs for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families. The Secretary will provide funding for housing programs for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families through State and local governments, as well as public and nonprofit organizations. Training for HUD personnel on issues related to grandparent-headed and relative-headed families will be provided. Training for HUD personnel on issues related to grandparent-headed and relative-headed families, including affordable housing opportunities and legal custody issues, will be provided as mandated by an amendment to Section 7 of the Department of Housing and Urban Development Act. SEC. 9. STUDY OF HOUSING NEEDS OF GRANDPARENT-HEADED AND RELATIVE-HEADED FAMILIES. The Secretary and the Director of the Bureau of the Census will conduct a study to estimate the number of covered families in the US and their affordable housing needs. A report with recommendations on major assisted housing programs must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The housing programs authorized by the United States Housing Act of 1937 and the supportive housing for the elderly program under the Housing Act of 1959 can be adapted to meet the affordable housing needs of covered families.
